name: filibuster

to make a long speech in order to delay or prevent a new law being made: Conceivably, supporters of the law could filibuster to prevent it from being revised.

a long speech that someone makes in order to delay or prevent a new law being made: He started a filibuster to stop the drafting of young men into military service.
More examplesFewer examplesThey can do so because of arcane rules that require a 60-vote majority to stop a filibuster.Last year the Nevada Senator staged a one-day filibuster, standing on the Senate floor and talking for eight hours and 35 minutes straight. During the civil rights battles of the 1950s and early 1960s, he defeated many anti-discrimination bills through filibusters and other delaying tactics.He threatened a last-minute filibuster against the measure.
